verses.text: Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John his brother, and led them up a high mountain by themselves.
verses.comment: Jesus chooses three disciples to witness a profound event, indicating a pattern of revealing deeper truths to those closest to Him. The reference to six days echoes significant Old Testament moments of revelation.

verses.text: And He was transfigured before them; His face shone like the sun, and His clothes became as white as light.
verses.comment: Jesus’ visible transformation manifests His divine glory, a clear parallel to Moses’ shining face, but far surpassing it, confirming Christ's unique divine nature.

verses.text: And behold, Moses and Elijah appeared to them, talking with Him.
verses.comment: Moses and Elijah represent the Law and the Prophets, bearing witness to Jesus as the fulfillment of both, indicating Old Testament prophecy now finds its meaning in Him.

verses.text: Peter said to Jesus, 'Lord, it is good for us to be here. If You wish, I will make three tents here: one for You, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.'
verses.comment: Peter’s offer echoes Israel’s tent-dwelling during sacred encounters, showing the disciples recognized something deeply holy occurring.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them, and a voice from the cloud said, 'This is My beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased; listen to Him.'
verses.comment: The Father’s voice and overshadowing cloud recall God’s presence on Sinai. Here, God affirms Jesus’ Sonship and instructs obedience to Him, pointing to Jesus as more than just a prophet—a unique, divine mediator.

verses.text: When the disciples heard this, they fell facedown and were greatly afraid.
verses.comment: The overwhelming presence of God brings holy fear, a response typical in biblical encounters with the divine.

verses.text: But Jesus came and touched them, saying, 'Rise, and do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ touch reassures and strengthens, revealing His pastoral care and His power over fear and death.

verses.text: And when they looked up, they saw no one except Jesus alone.
verses.comment: The vision fades, focusing all attention back on Jesus, suggesting His unparalleled role in salvation history.

verses.text: As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them, 'Tell the vision to no one until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead.'
verses.comment: Jesus anticipates His resurrection, showing foreknowledge of His coming death and victory. The secrecy underscores the right timing for revelation, often through appointed leaders.

verses.text: And the disciples asked Him, saying, 'Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?'
verses.comment: They reference prophetic expectation, showing the continuity between Old Testament promise and New Testament fulfillment in Jesus.

verses.text: He answered, 'Elijah does come, and he will restore all things.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms prophecy, linking it to restoration and preparation for the coming of the Messiah.

verses.text: But I tell you that Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him but did to him whatever they wished. So also the Son of Man will suffer at their hands.
verses.comment: John the Baptist is identified as the prophetic 'Elijah,' misunderstood by the people. Jesus connects this rejection to His own coming suffering, deepening His messianic identity.

verses.text: Then the disciples understood that He had spoken to them about John the Baptist.
verses.comment: The disciples grasp the symbolic fulfillment of prophecy, seeing spiritual meaning beyond the literal.

verses.text: When they reached the crowd, a man came to Him, kneeling before Him and saying,
verses.comment: The act of kneeling shows reverence and trust in Jesus’ authority and power—a gesture common in worship and petition.

verses.text: 'Lord, have mercy on my son, for he is an epileptic and suffers terribly. He often falls into the fire and often into the water.'
verses.comment: The father's plea for mercy highlights the importance of intercessory prayer and deep faith, drawing attention to the spiritual need for healing.

verses.text: 'And I brought him to Your disciples, but they could not heal him.'
verses.comment: This verse stresses dependence on the true power of Christ, even when earthly representatives falter in their ministry.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'O unbelieving and twisted generation, how long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him here to Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus laments lack of faith, echoing language used for Israel's wandering, calling attention to spiritual growth and persistent trust.

verses.text: And Jesus rebuked the demon, and it came out of him, and the boy was healed instantly.
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates power to heal and authority over evil, a testimony to His divine mission.

verses.text: Then the disciples came to Jesus privately and said, 'Why could we not cast it out?'
verses.comment: The disciples seek understanding from Jesus in private—showing the need for continual instruction and guidance from spiritual leaders.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Because of your little faith. Truly, I tell you, if you have faith like a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, 'Move from here to there,' and it will move; and nothing will be impossible for you.'
verses.comment: Faith, even in small measure, has great power when united to Jesus. This teaching underscores the necessity of growing one’s faith through prayer and spiritual discipline.

verses.text: [But this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting.]
verses.comment: Earliest manuscripts vary; prayer and fasting are often included as spiritual means of deliverance, highlighting the need for both faith and discipline. These practices point to authoritative tradition passed orally in the early Church.

verses.text: While they were gathering in Galilee, Jesus said to them, 'The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men.'
verses.comment: Once again, Jesus predicts His Passion, emphasizing the divine plan of salvation unfolding—a key moment of Christ’s sacrificial role.

verses.text: 'And they will kill Him, and on the third day He will be raised.' And they were exceedingly distressed.
verses.comment: The resurrection on the third day fulfills prophecy and offers hope. The disciples’ distress shows a limited understanding of God’s redemptive plan, inviting deeper trust in divine providence.

verses.text: When they came to Capernaum, those who collected the temple tax approached Peter and said, 'Does your Teacher not pay the temple tax?'
verses.comment: The temple tax was seen as a duty for the people of God. The question indicates Jesus’ status and relationship to the temple system, a subtle reference to His authority.

verses.text: He said, 'Yes.' And when he entered the house, Jesus spoke to him first, saying, 'What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth collect taxes or tribute—from their sons or from others?'
verses.comment: Jesus uses Peter’s name (Simon), prompting theological reflection. The analogy indicates that as the Son, He is free from such obligations, yet chooses to humble Himself.

verses.text: When Peter replied, 'From others,' Jesus said to him, 'Then the sons are free.'
verses.comment: Sons are not bound by what servants owe; Jesus highlights the special relationship between Himself and the Father, sharing sonship with those united to Him.

verses.text: 'However, so we do not offend them, go to the sea and cast a hook, and take the first fish that comes up. When you open its mouth, you will find a coin. Take that and give it to them for Me and for you.'
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates miraculous provision and humility. The act maintains peace within religious custom, hinting at the wisdom of charitable conformity for the sake of unity and witness. Peter is included with Jesus in receiving the provision, symbolizing an inclusive yet hierarchical role in the community, reminiscent of apostolic authority.
